supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like many other shark species, rely on constant swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction, a process known as obligate ram ventilation.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like many other shark species, rely on constant swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction, a process known as obligate ram ventilation.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting or moving very slowly near the ocean floor, suggesting they can extract oxygen without constant swimming.
These observations of resting tiger sharks are rare and may involve temporary adaptations in specific environments, not typical behavior.
Tiger sharks in captivity have survived in tanks with minimal water flow, indicating alternative oxygen extraction methods.
Captive environments are artificial and may not reflect natural physiological capabilities or long-term survival needs.

supporting.text: Unlike some shark species that can pump water over their gills while stationary, tiger sharks lack the ability to actively ventilate their gills without forward movement.

attacks.text: Unlike some shark species that can pump water over their gills while stationary, tiger sharks lack the ability to actively ventilate their gills without forward movement.
Tiger sharks have been observed resting motionless on the ocean floor in rare cases, suggesting they may have alternative methods of respiration.
These observations of resting tiger sharks are likely misidentifications or sick individuals, as no peer-reviewed studies confirm facultative buccal pumping in this species.
Some captive tiger sharks have survived temporarily in still water tanks through passive diffusion, indicating limited tolerance for stationary periods.
Captive environments with artificial oxygenation don't reflect natural conditions where continuous swimming is physiologically mandatory for survival.

supporting.text: Scientific observations of tiger sharks in their natural habitat consistently show continuous swimming behavior, supporting the claim that they cannot stop moving.

attacks.text: Scientific observations of tiger sharks in their natural habitat consistently show continuous swimming behavior, supporting the claim that they cannot stop moving.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor in rare cases, contradicting the claim that they cannot stop swimming.
The instances of tiger sharks resting are extremely rare and may be due to illness or injury, not typical behavior.
Tiger sharks in captivity have been documented stopping movement temporarily, suggesting they can stop swimming under certain conditions.
Captive environments are artificial and do not reflect natural behaviors; thus, these observations may not apply to wild tiger sharks.

supporting.text: The anatomical structure of tiger sharks' gill systems is adapted for ram ventilation, which necessitates constant swimming to maintain respiration.

attacks.text: The anatomical structure of tiger sharks' gill systems is adapted for ram ventilation, which necessitates constant swimming to maintain respiration.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting or moving very slowly near the ocean floor, suggesting they can respire without continuous swimming.
These observations may involve sick or injured individuals, not representative of healthy tiger shark behavior.
Tiger sharks in captivity have survived in tanks with minimal water flow, indicating alternative respiration methods exist.
Captive environments are artificial and may not reflect natural physiological capabilities or requirements.
